pr_title: Expose ResultSetStats in the Pinot client's ResultSetGroup

timeline.message:
Expose response stats in the Pinot client's BrokerResponse.

This would let the client application to observe and print response stats selectively
for queries and avoid reproducing slow queries.

timeline.bodyText: @kishoreg @npawar I'm not super convinced with this name but can't think of a better name than this. Feel free to suggest something else.
timeline.author: buchireddy

replies.bodyText: This isn't a rename. It's a new method addition.
replies.author: buchireddy

replies.bodyText: This isn't applicable anymore as per the latest change.
replies.author: buchireddy

timeline.bodyText: Don't rename the methods as it would not be backward compatible and will break other connectors such as JDBC.
timeline.author: KKcorps
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -96,6 +96,18 @@ public ResultSetGroup execute(Request request)
     return execute(null, request);
   }
 
+  /**
+   * Executes a Pinot Request and returns the Response.
+   *
+   * @param request The request to execute
+   * @return The BrokerResponse for the request.
+   * @throws PinotClientException If an exception occurs while processing the query
+   */
+  public BrokerResponse executeRequest(Request request)

replies.bodyText: This isn't a rename. It's a new method addition.
replies.author: buchireddy

replies.bodyText: My bad. @kishoreg should we have two methods both executing query - one returning the complete response while other returning the response table. IMO, we should have only one but if we remove the old one the JDBC connector will break.
replies.author: KKcorps

replies.bodyText: why not add the response stats as part of the existing return type. It maintains backwards compatibility and simply adds an additional method in ResultSetGroup
replies.author: kishoreg

replies.bodyText: I don't think the stats belong to ResultSetGroup, hence I didn't go that route. Yes, it's simple and easy method but isn't intuitive API, at least to me.
replies.author: buchireddy

replies.bodyText: Not really. There is scope for metadata and stats. https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/reference/rest/v1/ResultSet
replies.author: kishoreg

replies.bodyText:
Yes. JDBC also follows a similar theme where you can return a ResultSetMetadata along with the actual result.
BrokerResponse can change in the future but the query interface should be consistent.
replies.author: KKcorps

replies.bodyText: Fixed this now by exposing stats in the ResultSetGroup itself. Please check.
replies.author: buchireddy

timeline.bodyText: This class should be moved to a separate file.
timeline.author: KKcorps

replies.bodyText: Done.
replies.author: buchireddy

timeline.message: Make the BrokerResponse class and getResponseStats() method public.

timeline.author: buchireddy

replies.bodyText:
I think thee intention was to expose a standard ResultSet Interface from which the user can easily read the data.
Broker Response can have different fields depending upon whether SQL or PQL endpoint was queried.
replies.author: KKcorps

replies.bodyText: IMO, ResultSet makes sense for JDBC client but for the Java client, the entire BrokerResponse makes more sense.
replies.author: buchireddy

replies.bodyText: Fixed this now by exposing stats in the ResultSetGroup itself. Please check.
replies.author: buchireddy

timeline.message: Moving the BrokerResponseStats into a separate file.

Exposing ResponseStats from ResultSetGroup instead of BrokerResponse.

This allows the ResponseStats to be introduced without changing any of the current
methods of Connection or PreparedStatement and no backward compatibility issues.

timeline.bodyText: This should be a List as well since ResultSet is a list
timeline.author: KKcorps

replies.bodyText:
A single query only has one set of stats. AFAIK, ResultSet is a list because Pinot sends a separate set of results for each group when there is groupBy but that doesn't mean there will be multiple response stats.
@fx19880617 correct me if my understanding isn't correct.
replies.author: buchireddy

replies.bodyText: @buchireddy that's right. we don't need it to be part of each resultset
replies.author: kishoreg

replies.bodyText: cool.
replies.author: KKcorps

timeline.author: kishoreg

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: buchireddy

timeline.bodyText: can we create constants for strings?
timeline.author: kishoreg

replies.bodyText: Done.
replies.author: buchireddy

timeline.bodyText: can we simply maintain a reference to jsonNode and look it up in the respective methods. This will add perf overhead for high throughput use cases where the client code is not interested in all the stats
timeline.author: kishoreg

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: buchireddy

timeline.message:
s/ResultSetStats/ExecutionStats/
Also, reading the stats from the JsonNode on need basis instead of reading
them always to avoid the overhead for cases who doesn't read stats.
Pulling out the string literals into constants.
